[[University of Houston–Downtown]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]]) |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{flag|United States Army}} |serviceyears = 1988–2009 |unit = [[United States Army Reserve]] }} -'''Troy E. Nehls''' (born April 7, 1968) is an American politician and law enforcement officer who is the [[Member of Congress|representative]] for [[Texas's 22nd congressional district]]. Since 2013, he has served as the [[sheriff]] for [[Fort Bend County, Texas]]. +'''Troy E. Nehls''' (born April 7, 1968) is an American politician and law enforcement officer who is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for [[Texas's 22nd congressional district]]. From 2013 to 2021, he served as the [[sheriff]] for [[Fort Bend County, Texas]]. Nehls is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. == Early life and education == Nehls was born in [[Beaver Dam (town), Wisconsin|Beaver Dam, Wisconsin]]. His father, Edwin Nehls, served in the [[Korean War]] and as [[sheriff]] of [[Dodge County, Wisconsin]]. Nehls enlisted in the [[United States Army Reserve]] in 1988. He served [[tours of duty]] in Bosnia, Iraq, and Afghanistan, and earned two [[Bronze Star]]s.{{cite web|last=Sudhalter|first=Michael|date=June 15, 2012|title=Nehls Twins' careers highlighted by dedication to public service|url=https://www.chron.com/neighborhood/fortbend/news/article/Nehls-Twins-careers-highlighted-by-dedication-9486771.php|accessdate=June 23, 2020|work=Houston Chronicle}} He earned his [[bachelor's degree]] from [[Liberty University]] and a [[master's degree]] in criminal justice from [[University of Houston–Downtown]].{{cite web|url=https://www.katymagazineonline.com/post/sheriff-troy-nehls-a-legacy-of-public-service|title=Sheriff Troy Nehls: A Legacy of Public Service|first=Katy|last=Magazine|date=June 1, 2019|website=katymagazine|accessdate=July 1, 2020}} == Career == Nehls moved to [[Fort Bend County, Texas]], in 1994, and joined the police department of [[Richmond, Texas]]. In 1998, he was fired for reasons which included destruction of evidence.{{Cite web|url=https://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/news/2017/12/08/255526/fort-bend-county-sheriff-troy-nehls-wont-run-for-congress-in-2018/|title=Fort Bend County Sheriff Troy Nehls Won’t Run For Congress in 2018|first=Andrew|last=Schneider|date=December 8, 2017|website=Houston Public Media}} In 2004, Nehls was elected [[Texas constable|constable]] for Fort Bend County, while he was serving in Iraq. He retired from the Army Reserve with the rank of [[major]] in 2009. In November 2012, Nehls was elected sheriff of Fort Bend County, taking office in January 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.fbherald.com/sheriff-troy-nehls/article_1536a4f0-f2e3-11e2-8855-0019bb2963f4.html|title=Sheriff Troy Nehls: A career law enforcement officer who comes from a law enforcement family|first=David|last=Emswiler|website=Fort Bend Herald|date=July 22, 2013|accessdate=June 29, 2020}} He was re-elected in November 2016. Nehls formed an [[exploratory committee]] for {{ushr|TX|22}} in the 2018 elections against incumbent Republican [[Pete Olson]], but decided in December 2017 not to run for that office.{{cite web|url=http://www.fortbendstar.com/sheriff-wont-run-for-congress-2/|title=Sheriff won’t run for Congress|date=December 13, 2017|work=Fort Bend Star|first=Theresa D.|last=McClellan|accessdate=July 1, 2020}} In July 2019, he announced that he would not seek re-election as sheriff in 2020.{{cite web|url=https://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/NEHLS-14085330.php|title=Fort Bend County Sheriff Troy Nehls won’t seek another term|first=Brooke A.|last=Lewis|date=July 10, 2019|website=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=July 1, 2020}} == U.S. House of Representatives == {{Main|2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Texas#District 22}} In mid-July 2019, Nehls created a website where he asked Fort Bend County residents whether he should run for Congress in the 22nd congressional district, which covers [[Katy, Texas|Katy]], [[Sugar Land, Texas|Sugar Land]], and [[Pearland, Texas|Pearland]].{{cite web|url=https://www.fbherald.com/free/fort-bend-county-sheriff-troy-nehls-explores-run-for-congress/article_cdb8ecd0-aef9-11e9-ae02-f771ba0323f1.html|title=Fort Bend County Sheriff Troy Nehls explores run for Congress|first=Scott Reese|last=Willey|work=Fort Bend Herald|date=July 25, 2019|accessdate=June 23, 2020}} On July 25, 2019, Olson announced he would not seek re-election in 2020.{{cite web|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/elections-2020/2019/07/25/sugar-land-rep-pete-olson-will-not-run-re-election-district-expected-competitive-2020|title=Sugar Land Rep. Pete Olson will not run for re-election in district expected to be competitive in 2020|author=Tom Benning|date=25 July 2019|accessdate=25 July 2019|publisher=Dallas News}} In December 2019, Nehls announced that he would run for a House seat.{{cite web|url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Fort-Bend-s-Nehls-announces-bid-for-Congress-14890393.php|title=Fort Bend's Nehls announces bid for Congress|first=Jasper|last=Scherer|date=December 8, 2019|work=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=June 23, 2020}}

--- +++ @@ -1,50 +1,49 @@ {{short description|Businessman and former U.S. Ambassador to Japan}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Bill Hagerty | image = Ambassador Hagerty.jpg | jr/sr = United States Senator | state = [[Tennessee]] | term_start = January 3, 2021 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Lamar Alexander]] -| succeeding = [[Lamar Alexander]] | successor = | office1 = 30th [[United States Ambassador to Japan]] | president1 = [[Donald Trump]] | term_start1 = August 31, 2017 | term_end1 = July 22, 2019 | predecessor1 = [[Caroline Kennedy]] | successor1 = [[Joseph M. Young]] (acting) | office2 = Tennessee Commissioner of
Economic and Community Development | governor2 = [[Bill Haslam]] | term_start2 = February 14, 2011 | term_end2 = June 6, 2014 | predecessor2 = [[Matt Kisber]] | successor2 = Randy Boyd | birth_name = William Francis Hagerty IV | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|8|14}} | birth_place = [[Gallatin, Tennessee]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | spouse = {{marriage|Chrissy Hagerty|2001}} | children = 4 | education = [[Vanderbilt University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Juris Doctor|JD]]) }} -'''William Francis Hagerty IV''' (born August 14, 1959) is an American politician, diplomat, and businessman who is the [[United States Senate|United States senator-elect]] from [[Tennessee]], having been elected to succeed [[Lamar Alexander]] in [[2020 United States Senate election in Tennessee|2020]]. A member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], Hagerty served as the 30th [[List of ambassadors of the United States to Japan|United States ambassador to Japan]] from 2017 to 2019. +'''William Francis Hagerty IV''' (born August 14, 1959) is an American politician, diplomat, and businessman who is the [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Tennessee]], having been elected to succeed [[Lamar Alexander]] in [[2020 United States Senate election in Tennessee|2020]]. A member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], Hagerty served as the 30th [[List of ambassadors of the United States to Japan|United States ambassador to Japan]] from 2017 to 2019. Hagerty worked as an economic advisor and [[White House Fellows|White House fellow]] under President [[George H. W. Bush]]. He then began a career in private equity. Hagerty is the co-founder of Hagerty Peterson & Company, a [[private equity]] [[investment firm]]; he is a former managing director of the firm. From 2011 to 2014, Hagerty served as commissioner of the Tennessee Department of Economic and Community Development. He led a successful effort to bring a [[Major League Soccer]] franchise to Nashville, Tennessee. President Donald Trump nominated Hagerty to serve as U.S. Ambassador to Japan on March 27, 2017, and he was confirmed by the U.S. Senate on July 13, 2017 in an 86–12 vote. Hagerty was sworn in as the 30th United States Ambassador to Japan on July 27, 2017; he resigned the post in July 2019 to run for U.S. Senate. Hagerty ran for the [[U.S. Senate]] seat being vacated by [[Lamar Alexander]] in the [[2020 United States Senate election in Tennessee|2020 election]]. He won the Republican primary and defeated Democratic nominee [[Marquita Bradshaw]] in the general election. ==Early life and education== Hagerty is a native of [[Gallatin, Tennessee|Gallatin]], in [[Sumner County, Tennessee]]. He became an [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]], and was awarded the [[Distinguished Eagle Scout Award]] in 2017.{{cite news|last=Hubbard|first=Alex |date=April 24, 2017|title=Bill Hagerty named Distinguished Eagle Scout in Franklin ceremony |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/williamson/2017/04/24/bill-hagerty-named-distinguished-eagle-scout-franklin-ceremony/100836538/|work=The Tennessean|access-date=2020-06-03}} He is a 1977 graduate of [[Madisonville North Hopkins High School]] in Kentucky.{{cite news|last=Harvey|first=Laura|date=July 24, 2017|title=Madisonville-North Hopkins High School graduate confirmed as U.S. ambassador to Japan|url=https://www.kentuckynewera.com/news/ap/article_8d86c092-6ffe-11e7-bc0c-f39ff5b6e1f7.html|work=[[Kentucky New Era]]|access-date=2020-06-20}} He earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in 1981 from [[Vanderbilt University]] and a [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Vanderbilt Law School]] in 1984.{{cite news|title=Bill Hagerty '84 appointed as U.S. Ambassador to Japan|url=https://law.vanderbilt.edu/news/bill-hagerty-84-appointed-as-u-s-ambassador-to-japan/ |accessdate=July 31, 2017|publisher=Vanderbilt Law School|date=March 24, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PPP-1991-book1/pdf/PPP-1991-book1-doc-pg607.pdf|title=Appointment of the 1991–1992 White House Fellows|publisher=White House|accessdate=August 18, 2017}} == Career == Hagerty began his career at [[Boston Consulting Group]], culminating in a three-year assignment to [[Tokyo]]. Hagerty was an economic advisor and [[White House Fellows|White House Fellow]] in the administration of President [[George H. W. Bush]]{{cite news |last1=Haberkorn |first1=Jennifer |last2=Restuccia |first2= Andrew |date=August 28, 2016 |title=Trump taps Bush, Romney veterans for transition |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/trump-transition-team-227450 |newspaper=Politico |access-date=October 25, 2016}} and then began a career in private equity, initially at Trident Capital in [[Silicon Valley]]. Hagerty is the co-founder of Hagerty Peterson & Company, a [[private equity]] [[investment firm]]; he is a former managing director of the firm.{{cite news |last1=Collins|first1=Michael|title=1 Tennessee's Bill Hagerty sworn in as the U.S. ambassador to Japan |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2017/07/27/tennessees-bill-hagerty-sworn-u-s-ambassador-japan/515938001/|accessdate=July 31, 2017|newspaper=The Tennessean|date=July 27, 2017}} He served as a national finance chairman in the [[Mitt Romney 2008 presidential campaign]].{{cite news |last=Garrison |first=Joey |date=November 12, 2014 |title=ECD Commissioner Bill Hagerty to leave Haslam administration |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2014/11/12/ecd-commissioner-bill-hagerty-leave-haslam-administration/18912413/ |newspaper=The Tennessean|access-date=October 25, 2016}} From 2011 to 2014, Hagerty served as commissioner of the Tennessee Department of Economic and Community Development in the cabinet of Governor [[Bill Haslam]], where he played a role in investments by [[Bridgestone]], [[Calsonic Kansei]], and [[Nissan]] in Tennessee.{{Cite news |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/04/trump-name-nashvilles-bill-hagerty-ambassador-japan/96166922/|title=Trump to name Nashville's Bill Hagerty ambassador to Japan|newspaper=The Tennessean|access-date=January 5, 2017}} Hagerty has served on the board of CyMed, NEW Customer Services, [[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]], [[Ryman Hospitality Properties|Ryman Hospitality]], [[Pinnacle Financial Partners]], and R.J. O'Brien.{{cite web|title=Report for the Committee on Foreign Relations: Hagerty, William – Japan – May 2017 |url=https://www.state.gov/m/dghr/coc/270775.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606021250/https://www.state.gov/m/dghr/coc/270775.htm|url-status=dead|archive-date=June 6, 2017|publisher=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=July 31, 2017}}

{{Flagicon image|National Defense Service Medal.png}} [[National Defense Service Medal]] }} -'''Kaialiʻi Kahele''' (born March 28, 1974){{cite web |url=https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2016/07/25/hawaii-news/confident-kahele-faces-experienced-novice-challengers-in-district-1/ |title=Confident Kahele faces experienced, novice challengers in District 1 |date=July 25, 2016 |work=Hawaii Tribune-Herald}} is an American politician, educator, and commercial pilot from [[Hawaii]]. He currently serves as the U.S. representative from Hawaii's 1st district. From 2016 to 2020, he has served in the [[Hawaii Senate]] from the 1st district. Kahele is a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]],{{cite web|title=Kaiali'i Kahele|url=http://www.capitol.hawaii.gov/memberpage.aspx?member=kkahele&year=2017|publisher=Hawaii Legislature |accessdate=February 28, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Kaiali'i Kahele|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Kaiali%27i_Kahele|publisher=Ballotpedia|accessdate=February 28, 2017}} and the son of Hawaii Senate member [[Gil Kahele]]. +'''Kaialiʻi Kahele''' (born March 28, 1974){{cite web |url=https://www.hawaiitribune-herald.com/2016/07/25/hawaii-news/confident-kahele-faces-experienced-novice-challengers-in-district-1/ |title=Confident Kahele faces experienced, novice challengers in District 1 |date=July 25, 2016 |work=Hawaii Tribune-Herald}} is an American politician, educator, and commercial pilot from [[Hawaii]]. He currently serves as the U.S. representative from Hawaii's 2nd district. From 2016 to 2020, he has served in the [[Hawaii Senate]] from the 1st district. Kahele is a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]],{{cite web|title=Kaiali'i Kahele|url=http://www.capitol.hawaii.gov/memberpage.aspx?member=kkahele&year=2017|publisher=Hawaii Legislature |accessdate=February 28, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Kaiali'i Kahele|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Kaiali%27i_Kahele|publisher=Ballotpedia|accessdate=February 28, 2017}} and the son of Hawaii Senate member [[Gil Kahele]]. In January 2019, Kahele announced he would challenge [[Tulsi Gabbard]] in [[Hawaii's 2nd congressional district]] in [[2020 United States House of Representatives elections in Hawaii|2020]], but Gabbard eventually dropped out of the race to focus on her campaign for the [[2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries|Democratic presidential nomination]]. Kahele won the Democratic nomination on August 8, 2020.{{cite web|title=Democrats Kai Kahele and Ed Case cruising to general election for Congress|url=https://www.staradvertiser.com/2020/08/08/breaking-news/democrats-kai-kahele-and-ed-case-cruising-to-general-election-for-congress/|publisher=Star Advertiser|accessdate=August 9, 2020}} He won the general election, and will become the second [[Native Hawaiian]] to serve as a voting member of Congress since Hawaii achieved statehood.{{Cite web|title=Kai Kahele wins Hawaii House seat vacated by Tulsi Gabbard|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/kai-kahele-wins-hawaii-house-seat-vacated-tulsi-gabbard-n1246619|access-date=2020-11-06|website=NBC News|language=en}} ==Early life and education== Kahele is a Native Hawaiian whose family comes from the small fishing village of [[Miloliʻi, Hawaii|Miloliʻi]] in [[South Kona]]. He graduated from [[Hilo High School]] and attended [[Hawaiʻi Community College]] and the [[University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo]] before earning a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in education from the [[University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa]] in 1998.{{Cite web|title=Meet Kai|url=https://www.kaikahele.com/meet-kai/|access-date=2020-07-09|website=Kai Kahele|language=en-US}} As a member of the University of Hawai‘i at Mānoa's [[Hawaii Rainbow Warriors and Rainbow Wahine|Rainbow Warriors]] NCAA Division I Mens Volleyball Team, he was voted "Most Inspirational Teammate" by his team in 1997. He and his wife live with their daughters in Hilo, Kahele's lifetime home on [[Hawai‘i Island]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.capitol.hawaii.gov/memberpage.aspx?member=kkahele|title=Legislative Members|website=www.capitol.hawaii.gov|access-date=2018-04-16}} ==Career== ===Military service=== Kahele is a military and civilian pilot. He is a commissioned officer in the [[Hawaii Air National Guard]], where he continues to serve as a Lieutenant Colonel with the 201st Air Mobility Operations Squadron at [[Hickam Air Force Base]]. Kahele is a decorated combat veteran with multiple deployments to both Iraq and Afghanistan since 2005. He flew 108 combat sorties, logged 3,075 hours of military flight time, and commanded C-17 combat missions. Kahele is the recipient of numerous awards including the [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]], the [[Commendation Medal]], the Air Medal for combat missions flown in Afghanistan, the [[National Defense Service Medal]], the [[Global War on Terrorism Service Medal]], [[Armed Forces Reserve Medal]], Hawaii State Active Duty Medal and the [[Combat Readiness Medal]].{{Cite web|date=2019-03-26|title=Awards & Decorations|url=https://www.kaikahele.com/army/awards-and-decorations/|access-date=2020-07-09|website=Kai Kahele|language=en-US}} He has previously been named both Pacific Air Forces Guard Officer of the Year and Hawaiʻi Air National Guard Officer of the Year. He also flies as a civilian pilot for [[Hawaiian Airlines]].{{Cite web|date=2019-06-04|title=In His Father's Footsteps|url=http://www.midweek.com/kai-kahele/|access-date=2020-07-09|website=MidWeek|language=en-US}} Kahele has served as an adjunct faculty member at the [[University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo]].

--- +++ @@ -1,60 +1,60 @@ {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2020}} {{Infobox election | election_name = 2021 Speaker of the United States House of Representatives election | flag_image = Flag of the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives.svg | type = legislative -| reporting = 27.25 -| last_update = 2:44 +| reporting = 42.96 +| last_update = 3:00 | time_zone = [[Eastern Standard Time|EST]] | previous_election = 2019 Speaker of the United States House of Representatives election | previous_year = 2019 | next_election = 2023 Speaker of the United States House of Representatives election | next_year = 2023 | election_date = January 3, 2021 | seats_for_election = '''Needed to Win:''' Majority of the votes cast
433 votes cast, 217 needed for a majority | vote_type = Members' | image_size = x180px | image1 = [[File:Official photo of Speaker Nancy Pelosi in 2019.jpg|145px]] | candidate1 = [[Nancy Pelosi]] | leaders_seat1 = {{ushr|CA|12|T}} | party1 = Democratic Party (United States) - | popular_vote1 = 57 - | percentage1 = 48.3 + | popular_vote1 = 84 + | percentage1 = 45.2 | image2 = Kevin McCarthy, official photo, 116th Congress.jpg | candidate2 = [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]] | leaders_seat2 = {{ushr|CA|23|T}} | party2 = Republican Party (US) -| popular_vote2 = '''61''' -| percentage2 = '''51.7%''' +| popular_vote2 = '''101''' +| percentage2 = '''54.3%''' | image3 = | candidate3 = | leaders_seat3 = | party3 = | popular_vote3 = | percentage3 = | image4 = [[File:Seal of the United States House of Representatives.svg|85px|link=|alt=]] | candidate4 = ''Others / Present'' | leaders_seat4 = | party4 = - | popular_vote4 = 0 - | percentage4 = 0% + | popular_vote4 = 1 + | percentage4 = 0.5% | title = [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker]] | before_election = [[Nancy Pelosi]] | before_party = Democratic Party (US) | after_election = TBD | after_party = TBD }} The '''2021 Speaker of the United States House of Representatives election''' will take place on January 3, 2021, the day the [[United States House of Representatives]] convenes for the [[117th United States Congress|117th Congress]]. Incumbent [[Speaker of the U.S. House|speaker]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] has been designated by the Democrats for the post, and [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]], the Republican leader, has been designated as his party's candidate.{{cite web |last1=Pergram |first1=Chad |title=117th Congress may offer some surprises due to the pandemic |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/117th-congress-may-offer-some-surprises-due-to-the-pandemic |website=Fox News |publisher=Fox News |access-date=31 December 2020}} Outgoing [[U.S. Representative]] [[Justin Amash]], the sole member of the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] in the House, expressed interest in presiding as a "nonpartisan Speaker" in the event that neither party could agree on a Speaker.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Justin Amash on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1326398393502085126|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-11-30|website=Twitter|language=en}} There will be a maximum of 433 members voting, due to an undecided election in [[New York's 22nd congressional district]] and the death of Representative-elect [[Luke Letlow]] in [[Louisiana's 5th congressional district]].https://ballotpedia.org/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_New_York,_2020https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/29/luke-letlow-covid-congress-452218 __TOC__

Incumbent [[Speaker of the U.S. House|speaker]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] has been designated by the Democrats for the post, and [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]], the Republican leader, has been designated as his party's candidate.{{cite web |last1=Pergram |first1=Chad |title=117th Congress may offer some surprises due to the pandemic |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/117th-congress-may-offer-some-surprises-due-to-the-pandemic |website=Fox News |publisher=Fox News |access-date=31 December 2020}} Outgoing [[U.S. Representative]] [[Justin Amash]], the sole member of the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] in the House, expressed interest in presiding as a "nonpartisan Speaker" in the event that neither party could agree on a Speaker.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Justin Amash on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1326398393502085126|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-11-30|website=Twitter|language=en}} There will be a maximum of 433 members voting, due to an undecided election in [[New York's 22nd congressional district]] and the death of Representative-elect [[Luke Letlow]] in [[Louisiana's 5th congressional district]].https://ballotpedia.org/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_New_York,_2020https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/29/luke-letlow-covid-congress-452218 __TOC__

433 votes cast, 217 needed for a majority | vote_type = Members' | image_size = x180px | image1 = [[File:Official photo of Speaker Nancy Pelosi in 2019.jpg|145px]] | candidate1 = [[Nancy Pelosi]] | leaders_seat1 = {{ushr|CA|12|T}} | party1 = Democratic Party (United States) | popular_vote1 = 187 - | percentage1 = 49.8% + | percentage1 = 49.2% | image2 = Kevin McCarthy, official photo, 116th Congress.jpg | candidate2 = [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]] | leaders_seat2 = {{ushr|CA|23|T}} | party2 = Republican Party (US) | popular_vote2 = 189 -| percentage2 = 49.9% +| percentage2 = 49.7% | image3 = | candidate3 = | leaders_seat3 = | party3 = | popular_vote3 = | percentage3 = | image4 = [[File:Seal of the United States House of Representatives.svg|85px|link=|alt=]] | candidate4 = ''Others / Present'' | leaders_seat4 = | party4 = | popular_vote4 = 5 - | percentage4 = % + | percentage4 = 1.3% | title = [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker]] | before_election = [[Nancy Pelosi]] | before_party = Democratic Party (US) | after_election = TBD | after_party = TBD }} The '''2021 Speaker of the United States House of Representatives election''' will take place on January 3, 2021, the day the [[United States House of Representatives]] convenes for the [[117th United States Congress|117th Congress]]. Incumbent [[Speaker of the U.S. House|speaker]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] has been designated by the Democrats for the post, and [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]], the Republican leader, has been designated as his party's candidate.{{cite web |last1=Pergram |first1=Chad |title=117th Congress may offer some surprises due to the pandemic |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/117th-congress-may-offer-some-surprises-due-to-the-pandemic |website=Fox News |publisher=Fox News |access-date=31 December 2020}} Outgoing [[U.S. Representative]] [[Justin Amash]], the sole member of the [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian Party]] in the House, expressed interest in presiding as a "nonpartisan Speaker" in the event that neither party could agree on a Speaker.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Justin Amash on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/1326398393502085126|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-11-30|website=Twitter|language=en}} There will be a maximum of 433 members voting, due to an undecided election in [[New York's 22nd congressional district]] and the death of Representative-elect [[Luke Letlow]] in [[Louisiana's 5th congressional district]].https://ballotpedia.org/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_New_York,_2020https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/29/luke-letlow-covid-congress-452218 __TOC__

--- +++ @@ -17,31 +17,31 @@ |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|9|25}} |birth_place = [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = Patrick Erwin |education = [[University of Washington]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Clark Atlanta University]] ([[Master of Business Administration|MBA]]) |website = {{url|stricklandforwashington.com|Campaign website}} |module = {{Infobox Korean name |child = yes |hangul = 순자 |hanja = |rr = Sun-ja |mr = Suncha}} }} -'''Marilyn Strickland''' (born September 25, 1962) is a South Korean-born American politician and businesswoman who is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative-elect]] for [[Washington's 10th congressional district]]. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], she will begin her first term on January 3, 2021. Strickland previously served as the 38th Mayor of [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]] from 2010 to 2018. She will be the first member of the [[United States Congress]] who is of both [[Korean Americans|Korean]] and [[African Americans|African American]] heritage. Strickland is also one of the first three Korean-American women ever elected to Congress, the other two being [[Young Kim]] and [[Michelle Steel]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/marilyn-strickland-s-black-korean-american-roots-are-historic-1st-n1246705|title=Marilyn Strickland's Black, Korean American roots are 1st for Congress|website=NBC News}} +'''Marilyn Strickland''' (born September 25, 1962) is a South Korean-born American politician and businesswoman who is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for [[Washington's 10th congressional district]]. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], she began begin her first term on January 3, 2021. Strickland previously served as the 38th Mayor of [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]] from 2010 to 2018. She will be the first member of the [[United States Congress]] who is of both [[Korean Americans|Korean]] and [[African Americans|African American]] heritage. Strickland is also one of the first three Korean-American women ever elected to Congress, the other two being [[Young Kim]] and [[Michelle Steel]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/marilyn-strickland-s-black-korean-american-roots-are-historic-1st-n1246705|title=Marilyn Strickland's Black, Korean American roots are 1st for Congress|website=NBC News}} == Early life and education == Strickland was born on September 25, 1962 in [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]], the daughter of Inmin Kim, a Korean mother and African-American father, Willie Strickland.{{Cite web|last=Baarsma|first=Bill|date=September 2, 2018|title=Marilyn Strickland (1962- ) •|url=https://www.blackpast.org/african-american-history/strickland-marilyn-1962/|access-date=August 6, 2020|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|last=Ebersole|first=Brian|date=December 27, 2017|title=From 'scary-bright' pupil to world-class mayor|work=The News Tribune|url=https://www.thenewstribune.com/opinion/article192173409.html}} Strickland and her family moved to [[Tacoma, Washington]] in 1967 after her father was stationed at [[Fort Lewis]]. She was raised in the South End neighborhood of Tacoma and attended [[Mount Tahoma High School]]. Strickland earned a degree in business from the [[University of Washington]] and an MBA from [[Clark Atlanta University]].{{Cite web|title=Marilyn Strickland|url=https://www.upforgrowth.org/person/marilyn-strickland|website=www.upforgrowth.org|language=en|access-date=May 19, 2020}} == Career == After graduating from the [[University of Washington]], Strickland took a job opportunity at Northern Life Insurance doing clerical work. She was introduced to Seattle Mayor [[Norm Rice]] at a luncheon, who suggested that she further her education. After earning a [[Master of Business Administration]] from [[Clark Atlanta University]], Strickland joined [[Starbucks]] as a manager of its online business. Strickland then moved on to help launch the City of [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]]’s public broadband cable service [[Click! Network|Click!]], working with an advertisement agency to help grow public support.{{Cite web|title=Working Geek: Former Mayor Marilyn Strickland is Seattle Metro Chamber's uniter in chief|url=https://www.geekwire.com/2019/working-geek-former-mayor-marilyn-strickland-seattle-metro-chambers-uniter-chief/|date=February 8, 2019|website=GeekWire|language=en-US|access-date=May 19, 2020}} After years in the private sector, Strickland was elected to the [[Tacoma City Council]]. She served as a council member for two years before being selected to serve as mayor from 2010 to 2018.{{Cite web|title=Marilyn Strickland|url=https://danielrosecenter.org/people/marilyn-strickland/|access-date=August 5, 2020|website=The Rose Center|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.tacomahistory.org/media/dynamic/files/597_Tacoma_Mayors.pdf|title=Chronology of Tacoma Mayors}} Strickland was the first Asian-born elected mayor of Tacoma, as well as the first African-American woman in that office. Strickland used connections in China and Vietnam to draw foreign investors, culminating in the visit to Tacoma of Chinese President [[Xi Jinping]].{{Cite web|title=Marilyn Strickland, Seattle chamber CEO and former Tacoma mayor, to run for Congress|url=https://www.knkx.org/post/marilyn-strickland-seattle-chamber-ceo-and-former-tacoma-mayor-run-congress|last=Plog|first=Kari|website=www.knkx.org|language=en|access-date=May 19, 2020}} In May 2010, the Tacoma Board of Ethics sanctioned Mayor Marilyn Strickland for accepting [[frequent flyer miles]] from a local businessman for an official trip to Asia. Strickland accepted the sanction and returned the value of the frequent flyer miles to the businessman.[https://archive.is/20120715223304/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2015104931_apwatacomamayorethics.html "Tacoma Board of Ethics says mayor violated code"]

edits.diff:
--- +++ @@ -216,17 +216,20 @@ Kelly appealed to the US Supreme Court, and on December 3, 2020 Justice [[Samuel Alito]] set a deadline of December 9, one day after the safe-harbor date for Pennsylvania officials to respond to the request to throw out the state's mail-in voting results, or possibly even the entire election.{{cite web|last1=Reed Ward|first1=Paula|title=Supreme Court sets date for state response in Mike Kelly election suit. Is it a day late?|url=https://triblive.com/local/regional/supreme-court-sets-date-for-state-response-in-mike-kelly-election-suit-is-it-a-day-late/|access-date=December 5, 2020|website=TribLive|publisher=Trib Total Media}}{{cite web|last1=Palattella|first1=Ed|title=U.S. Supreme Court scheduling order foils U.S. Rep. Mike Kelly's push to get voting suit heard quickly|url=https://www.goerie.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/12/04/supreme-court-scheduling-order-seems-foil-mike-kellys-voting-suit/3825984001/|access-date=December 5, 2020|website=GoErie|publisher=Erie Times-News}} But, the deadline was later changed to 9 am, December 8, so within the safe-harbor deadline. In complying with the change, the Commonwealth's attorneys stated:
"Petitioners [Kelly and others] ask this Court to undertake one of the most dramatic, disruptive invocations of judicial power in the history of the Republic. No court has ever issued an order nullifying a governor's certification of presidential election results. And for good reason: "Once the door is opened to judicial invalidation of presidential election results, it will be awfully hard to close that door again. . . . The loss of public trust in our constitutional order resulting from the exercise of this kind of judicial power would be incalculable."{{Cite web|date=December 8, 2020|title=PA Election Lawyers Urge Justice Alito to Reject One of the Most ‘Dramatic, Disruptive’ Cases of All Time|url=https://lawandcrime.com/2020-election/pa-election-lawyers-urge-justice-alito-to-reject-one-of-the-most-dramatic-disruptive-cases-of-all-time/}}
On December 8, 2020 the Supreme Court rejected the request in a one-sentence, unsigned order;{{Cite web|author=|date=December 8, 2020|title=The Supreme Court has rejected Republicans' request to overturn Biden's Pennsylvania win|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/supreme-court-rejects-gops-request-to-overturn-biden-pennsylvania-win-2020-12|access-date=December 8, 2020|work=Business Insider|quote=rejected a request to overturn}}{{Cite news|last=Barnes|first=Robert|last2=Viebeck|first2=Elise|date=December 8, 2020|title=Supreme Court denies Trump allies' bid to overturn Pennsylvania election results|newspaper=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/supreme-court-trump-pennsylvania-election-results/2020/12/08/4d39e16c-397d-11eb-98c4-25dc9f4987e8_story.html}}{{cite web|author1=Supreme Court of the United States|author1-link=Supreme Court of the United States|date=December 8, 2020|title=20A98: KELLY, MIKE, ET AL. V. PENNSYLVANIA, ET AL.|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/120820zr_bq7d.pdf|access-date=December 9, 2020|website=Orders of the Court - Term Year 2020|quote=The application for injunctive relief presented to Justice Alito and by him referred to the Court is denied.}} by the time of the high court's decision, the Pennsylvania election results had been certified in Biden's favor.{{Cite web|date=November 24, 2020|title=Biden certified as winner of Pennsylvania presidential vote|url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-pennsylvania-elections-8a61a1609d7a0d60c1db13fa8e7c3019|website=AP NEWS}}{{Cite web|last=Liptak|first=Adam|date=December 8, 2020|title=Supreme Court Rejects Republican Challenge to Pennsylvania Vote|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/08/us/supreme-court-republican-challenge-pennsylvania-vote.html|work=The New York Times}} == ''Pirkle v. Wolf'' == On November 10, 2020, four voters sued to block votes from being counted in [[Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Montgomery]], [[Delaware County, Pennsylvania|Delaware]] and [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Allegheny]] counties. The plaintiffs claimed the state violated [[Right to equal protection|the right to equal protection]] by allowing counties to have varying practices for mail-in ballots. Porter Wright, the law firm that represented the Trump campaign, asked to withdraw. On November 16, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the suit. The claims made by plaintiffs in this lawsuit are similar to ''Brooks v. Mahoney'' and ''Bally v. Whitmer''; these lawsuits were all filed by conservative lawyer [[James Bopp]]. The plaintiffs also cited ''Trump v. Boockvar''.{{Cite web|last1=Kovacs-Goodman|first1=Jacob|last2=Levine|first2=Zahavah|date=November 17, 2020|title=Post-Election Litigation in Battleground States|url=https://healthyelections.org/sites/default/files/2020-11/Post-Election-Litigation-Update-111720.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118145037/https://healthyelections.org/sites/default/files/2020-11/Post-Election-Litigation-Update-111720.pdf|archive-date=November 18, 2020|access-date=November 18, 2020|website=healthyelections.org}}{{Cite web|title=#20 in Pirkle v. Wolf (M.D. Penn., 4:20-cv-02088) – CourtListener.com|url=http://www.courtlistener.com/docket/18619851/20/pirkle-v-wolf/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118210524/https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/18619851/20/pirkle-v-wolf/|archive-date=November 18, 2020|access-date=November 16, 2020|website=CourtListener|language=en-us}} == ''Ziccarelli v. Allegheny Cty. Bd. of Elections'' == === November 12 lawsuit === On November 12, 2020, Nicole Ziccarelli, a Republican state Senate candidate, sued the Allegheny County Board of Elections in state court. The plaintiff claimed that the board improperly counted 2,349 mail-in ballots that were not dated by the voter, and sought to exclude these votes from being counted. On November 18, 2020, the state's Court of Common Pleas denied the plaintiffs request, ordering the votes to be counted. Ziccarelli appealed the decision on November 19; the following day, the state's Commonwealth Court ruled that the election code requires the voter to date their ballot, and the 2,349 ballots in question should not be counted.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Ziccarelli v. Allegheny County Board of Elections I|url=https://healthyelections-case-tracker.stanford.edu/detail?id=378|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201209180631/https://healthyelections-case-tracker.stanford.edu/detail?id=378|archive-date=December 9, 2020|access-date=November 24, 2020|website=Stanford-MIT Healthy Elections Project}}{{Cite web|last=Routh|first=Julian|date=November 19, 2020|title=Court strikes down counting of 2,349 ballots in Allegheny County|url=https://www.post-gazette.com/news/politics-state/2020/11/19/Nicole-Ziccarelli-PA-state-Senate-vs-Brewster-election-ballots-Commonwealth-Court/stories/202011190151|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120033140/https://www.post-gazette.com/news/politics-state/2020/11/19/Nicole-Ziccarelli-PA-state-Senate-vs-Brewster-election-ballots-Commonwealth-Court/stories/202011190151|archive-date=November 20, 2020|access-date=November 24, 2020|website=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|language=en}} The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania consolidated this case with ''In re: Canvass of Absentee and Mail-In Ballots of November 3, 2020, Gen. Election,'' and on November 23, affirmed the decision of the decision of the Allegheny County Board of Elections to count the 2,349 ballots at issue.{{Cite web|title=Pa. Supreme Court allows count of 2,000 ballots challenged by Nicole Ziccarelli|url=https://www.post-gazette.com/news/crime-courts/2020/11/23/Pa-Supreme-Court-allows-count-ballots-challenged-Nicole-Ziccarelli-jim-brewster/stories/202011230112|access-date=December 5, 2020|website=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|language=en}} === November 16 lawsuit === On November 16, 2020, Nicole Ziccarelli, a Republican state Senate candidate, filed a second lawsuit in state court against the Allegheny County Board of Elections. Ziccarelli challenged the decision of the board to count 270 provisional ballots that lacked one of two signatures. The Court of Common Pleas ruled that the ballots should be counted. Ziccarelli appealed; the Commonwealth Court reversed the lower court's decision, ruling that the statute at issue requires both signatures and the ballots should not be counted. On November 23, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court denied the board's petition for appeal.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Ziccarelli v. Allegheny County Board of Elections II|url=https://healthyelections-case-tracker.stanford.edu/detail?id=385|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201209182015/https://healthyelections-case-tracker.stanford.edu/detail?id=385|archive-date=December 9, 2020|access-date=December 9, 2020|website=Stanford-MIT Healthy Elections Project}} +== Notes == +{{notelist}} + == References == -{{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} +{{reflist}}

edits.diff:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -115,16 +115,16 @@
 Justice Hagedorn wrote the 4-3 ruling against the Trump campaign, saying the campaign waited too long to bring the suit and should have brought the challenge before the election.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Journal|first=Riley Vetterkind {{!}} Wisconsin State|title=Wisconsin Supreme Court rejects Donald Trump's election challenge; electors vote for Joe Biden|url=https://madison.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/elections/wisconsin-supreme-court-rejects-donald-trumps-election-challenge-electors-vote-for-joe-biden/article_d82d99c1-25a5-53ad-bd55-e0998efd86a5.html|access-date=2020-12-15|website=madison.com|language=en|archive-date=2020-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074405/https://madison.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/elections/wisconsin-supreme-court-rejects-donald-trumps-election-challenge-electors-vote-for-joe-biden/article_d82d99c1-25a5-53ad-bd55-e0998efd86a5.html|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 Following the ruling, justices Karofsky and Dallet received misogynistic and anti-Semitic online comments; with neo-Nazi website ''[[The Daily Stormer]]'' highlighting their Jewish heritage.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sales |first1=Ben |title=2 Jewish Wisconsin judges denounced a Trump lawsuit. Now anti-Semites are harassing them. |url=https://www.jta.org/2020/12/17/politics/2-jewish-wisconsin-judges-denounced-a-trump-lawsuit-now-anti-semites-are-harassing-them |access-date=December 26, 2020 |agency=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]] |date=December 17, 2020 |archive-date=December 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074550/https://www.jta.org/2020/12/17/politics/2-jewish-wisconsin-judges-denounced-a-trump-lawsuit-now-anti-semites-are-harassing-them |url-status=live }}</ref> Justice Hagedorn, who was personally criticized by President Trump after the ruling, was also subjected to harassment. Wisconsin chief justice Roggensack reacted by condemning the "threats of actual or proposed violence" faced by the justices.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Glauber |first1=Bill |title=Wisconsin Supreme Court Chief Justice Patience Roggensack expresses concern over threats, comments aimed at members of her court |url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/12/25/justice-roggensack-concerned-over-wisconsin-supreme-court-criticism/4045914001/ |access-date=December 26, 2020 |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |date=December 25, 2020 |archive-date=December 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074357/https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/12/25/justice-roggensack-concerned-over-wisconsin-supreme-court-criticism/4045914001/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 == ''Trump v. Wisconsin Elections Commission'' ==
 On December 2, 2020, Donald Trump, in his capacity as a candidate for president, filed a lawsuit in federal district court against the Wisconsin Elections Commission.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Docket for Trump v. The Wisconsin Elections Commission, 2:20-cv-01785|url=https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/18710035/trump-v-the-wisconsin-elections-commission/|access-date=December 5, 2020|website=CourtListener|archive-date=December 30, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074359/https://www.courtlistener.com/docket/18710035/trump-v-the-wisconsin-elections-commission/|url-status=live}}</ref> The campaign alleged that several election officials committed unconstitutional acts,<ref name=":109">{{Cite news|last=Danbeck|first=Jackson|date=December 2, 2020|title=Trump campaign files 2nd lawsuit, this time against Wisconsin Elections Commission|work=[[WTMJ-TV]]|url=https://www.tmj4.com/news/election-2020/trump-campaign-files-2nd-lawsuit-this-time-against-wisconsin-elections-commission|url-status=live|access-date=December 5, 2020|archive-date=December 30, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074405/https://www.tmj4.com/news/election-2020/trump-campaign-files-2nd-lawsuit-this-time-against-wisconsin-elections-commission}}</ref><ref name=":110">{{Cite web|last=Jannene|first=Jeramy|date=December 4, 2020|title=Trump Sues Again, This Time in Milwaukee and Dane Counties|url=https://urbanmilwaukee.com/2020/12/03/trump-files-second-suit-seeking-to-throw-out-wisconsin-election/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201204170929/https://urbanmilwaukee.com/2020/12/04/trump-sues-again-this-time-in-milwaukee-and-dane-counties/|archive-date=December 4, 2020|access-date=December 8, 2020|website=Urban Milwaukee}}</ref> and the risk of voter fraud was increased because of how absentee ballots were handled.<ref name=":111">{{Cite web|last=Bauer|first=Scott|date=2020-12-10|title=Federal judge casts doubt on Trump's Wisconsin lawsuit|url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-legislature-madison-8adc2e137d85d0fee64c5a6cb6421f3f|access-date=2020-12-12|website=AP NEWS|archive-date=2020-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074455/https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-legislature-madison-8adc2e137d85d0fee64c5a6cb6421f3f|url-status=live}}</ref> The campaign challenged various directives given by the Wisconsin Elections Commission and claimed that a plan setting up absentee ballot drop boxes, made by the mayors of Milwaukee, Madison, Kenosha, Green Bay and Racine, was implemented without adequate security measures.<ref name=":109" /><ref name=":111" /> The campaign also challenged the ballots of those who voted without showing a photo ID, after declaring themselves "indefinitely confined".<ref name=":111" /><ref>{{Cite web|last=Johnson|first=Shawn|date=2020-12-10|title=Federal Judge: 'Incredible' That Trump Waited To File Wisconsin Lawsuit|url=https://www.wpr.org/federal-judge-incredible-trump-waited-file-wisconsin-lawsuit|access-date=2020-12-12|website=Wisconsin Public Radio|language=en|archive-date=2020-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074607/https://www.wpr.org/federal-judge-incredible-trump-waited-file-wisconsin-lawsuit|url-status=live}}</ref>  For the challenged Wisconsin Elections Commission policies, the policy on witness addresses was issued in 2016, and updated in 2020; the policy on the qualifying criteria for "indefinitely confined" voter status during the COVID-19 pandemic was announced in March 2020; and the policy allowing absentee ballot drop boxes was enacted in August 2020.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sullum |first1=Jacob |title=A Trump Appointee Rejects Election Complaints Similar to the Ones SCOTUS Declined to Hear |url=https://reason.com/2020/12/14/a-trump-appointee-rejects-election-complaints-similar-to-the-ones-scotus-declined-to-hear/ |access-date=December 26, 2020 |work=[[Reason (website)|Reason]] |date=December 14, 2020}}</ref> As a remedy, the campaign asked the court to overturn the results of the election and send the matter to the state legislature.<ref name=":109" /><ref name=":110" />
 
 On December 12, Trump-appointed U.S. District Judge [[Brett H. Ludwig|Brett Ludwig]] dismissed the case with prejudice. Judge Ludwig described the case as "''extraordinary''" with "even more ''extraordinary''" relief sought. The judge ruled that the Trump campaign's "Electors Clause claims fail as a matter of law and fact" and that the opposite was proven: Wisconsin's presidential electors were determined exactly in the way the Wisconsin legislature intended, because the Wisconsin legislature had ordered the Wisconsin Election Commission to decide the rules of the election. The judge also noted that since the lawsuit was about "disputed issues of election administration" practices, Trump could have filed the lawsuit before the vote occurred, but failed to do so. The judge concluded that Trump "lost on the merits" in this case.<ref name="Ludwig1">{{Cite news|last=Marley|first=Patrick|date=December 12, 2020|title=Federal court judge dismisses 'extraordinary' Trump lawsuit seeking to overturn Wisconsin election|work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2020/12/12/trump-wisconsin-lawsuit-dismissed-federal-judge/3894689001/|url-status=live|access-date=December 12, 2020|archive-date=December 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201212205957/https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2020/12/12/trump-wisconsin-lawsuit-dismissed-federal-judge/3894689001/}}</ref><ref name="Ludwig2">{{Cite news|last1=Larson|first1=Erik|date=December 13, 2020|title=Trump's Wisconsin Election Suit Dismissed by Federal Judge|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-12/trump-s-wisconsin-election-suit-dismissed-by-federal-judge|url-status=live|access-date=December 13, 2020|archiveurl=https://archive.ph/NsKFq|archivedate=December 13, 2020}}</ref>
 
 Trump appealed to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]], where a three-judge panel unanimously "affirmed" the district court's ruling.<ref name=Glauber1>{{cite news |last1=Glauber |first1=Bill |title=Federal appeals court turns down Donald Trump push to overturn election results in Wisconsin |url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/12/24/federal-appeals-court-rejects-trump-bid-overturn-wisconsin-results/4043650001/ |access-date=December 26, 2020 |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] |date=December 25, 2020 |archive-date=December 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074455/https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/12/24/federal-appeals-court-rejects-trump-bid-overturn-wisconsin-results/4043650001/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The panel ruled that Trump's "claims fail under the Electors Clause", because the Wisconsin legislature had given the Wisconsin Elections Commission the "authority" to manage the election, therefore there was no constitutional violation: Wisconsin's presidential electors were "lawfully appointed its electors in the manner directed by" the Wisconsin legislature.<ref name=Glauber1/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Gerstein |first1=Josh |title=Trump campaign suffers another legal setback in Wisconsin case |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/24/trump-loses-wisconsin-georgia-450433 |access-date=December 27, 2020 |work=[[Politico]] |date=December 24, 2020 |archive-date=December 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074454/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/24/trump-loses-wisconsin-georgia-450433 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=WBAY25>{{cite news |title=U.S. Appeals Court rules against Trump in suit challenging Wisconsin election |url=https://www.wbay.com/2020/12/24/us-appeals-court-rules-against-trump-in-suit-challenging-wisconsin-election/ |access-date=December 26, 2020 |work=[[WBAY]] |date=December 25, 2020 |archive-date=December 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230063006/https://www.wbay.com/2020/12/24/us-appeals-court-rules-against-trump-in-suit-challenging-wisconsin-election/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Trump's claims also failed due to "the unreasonable delay" in challenging the potential constitutional violation; entertaining such a late lawsuit would result in "unquestionable harm" to Wisconsin voters, ruled the judges.<ref name=WBAY25/><ref name=AP25>{{cite news |title=Court affirms ruling dismissing Trump challenge in Wisconsin |url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-wisconsin-state-elections-21be0822f83b937cab9a4ff133e92941 |access-date=December 26, 2020 |work=[[Associated Press]] |date=December 25, 2020 |archive-date=December 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230074456/https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-wisconsin-state-elections-21be0822f83b937cab9a4ff133e92941 |url-status=live }}</ref> The appeals court decision was written by [[Michael Y. Scudder|Michael Scudder Jr.]], a Trump appointee, while the other two judges, [[Joel Flaum]] and [[Ilana Rovner]], were also Republican-appointed.<ref name=Glauber1/><ref name=AP25/>
 
 == ''Wisconsin Voters Alliance v. Wisconsin Elections Commission'' ==
 On November 23, 2020, a group of Republican voters, the Wisconsin Voters Alliance, filed a lawsuit in the Wisconsin Supreme Court against the [[Wisconsin Elections Commission]]. The voters claimed that a [[Mark Zuckerberg]]-funded organization, Center for Technology and Civic Life, gave $6 million to the cities of [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]], [[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]] and [[Milwaukee]] in order to facilitate the casting of tens of thousands of illegal ballots. The group said Trump would have won the state without the inclusion of those ballots; as a remedy, they asked the court to stop the certification of the election, allow the state legislature to appoint electors, and order the governor to certify those electors. Democratic Attorney General [[Josh Kaul]] released a statement the following day, saying the litigation seeks to disenfranchise voters, and that his department "will ensure that Wisconsin's presidential electors are selected based on the will of the more than 3 million Wisconsin voters who cast a ballot."<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Wisconsin Voters Alliance vs. Wisconsin Election Commissions|url=https://healthyelections-case-tracker.stanford.edu/detail?id=393|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201129201501/https://healthyelections-case-tracker.stanford.edu/detail?id=393|archive-date=November 29, 2020|access-date=November 29, 2020|website=Stanford-MIT Healthy Elections Project}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite web|last1=Tornabene|first1=Juliana|last2=Baik|first2=Michelle|date=November 24, 2020|title=Group asks state high court to toss election results and order legislature to pick electors|url=https://www.nbc15.com/2020/11/24/voter-group-files-lawsuit-against-the-wisconsin-elections-commission-over-election-results/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201124223144/https://www.nbc15.com/2020/11/24/voter-group-files-lawsuit-against-the-wisconsin-elections-commission-over-election-results/|archive-date=November 24, 2020|access-date=November 29, 2020|website=nbc15.com|language=en|agency=Associated Press}}</ref><ref name=":12">{{Cite web|last=Bauer|first=Scott|date=November 24, 2020|title=Republicans sue to stop Wisconsin vote certification|url=https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-madison-wisconsin-7882adcf4ed8fc941fa6948e1da9e5ab|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201128032408/https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-joe-biden-donald-trump-madison-wisconsin-7882adcf4ed8fc941fa6948e1da9e5ab|archive-date=November 28, 2020|access-date=November 29, 2020|website=AP NEWS}}</ref> On December 4, the court rejected the petition, with Justice Brian Hagedorn writing: "Once the door is opened to judicial invalidation of presidential election results, it will be awfully hard to close that door again. This is a dangerous path we are being asked to tread."<ref name=":83">{{Cite web|last1=Cheney|first1=Kyle|last2=Gerstein|first2=Josh|date=December 4, 2020|title=Donald Trump's brutal day in court|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/04/donald-trump-in-court-443010|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201205143732/https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/04/donald-trump-in-court-443010|archive-date=December 5, 2020|access-date=December 5, 2020|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":85">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Wisconsin Supreme Court Order (Wisconsin Voters Alliance v. Wisconsin Elections Commission)|url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/11/2020AP1930-OAfinal-12-4-20.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201205203748/https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/11/2020AP1930-OAfinal-12-4-20.pdf|archive-date=December 5, 2020|access-date=December 5, 2020|website=Democracy Docket}}</ref>

@@ -101,20 +101,18 @@
 The Trump campaign requested that their evidence be kept secret from the public, but the judge refused to allow the secrecy.<ref name="Polletta1">{{cite news|last1=Polletta|first1=Maria|date=November 10, 2020|title=Judge rejects Trump team's request for secret evidence in lawsuit over Maricopa County votes|work=[[Arizona Republic]]|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/11/10/trump-lawsuit-maricopa-county-votes-secret-evidence-kory-langhofer-thomas-liddy/6242176002/|url-status=live|accessdate=November 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116052309/https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/11/10/trump-lawsuit-maricopa-county-votes-secret-evidence-kory-langhofer-thomas-liddy/6242176002/|archive-date=November 16, 2020}}</ref> The Trump campaign also stated that they had video footage from within a polling area, however, such footage would be illegal if taken within {{convert|75|ft}} of a polling area with voters present.<ref name="Polletta1" /> The Trump campaign attempted to submit affidavits they collected, but admitted that some of these affidavits were "false" or "spam"; the judge refused to accept the affidavits as evidence, calling them unreliable.<ref name="Polletta2">{{cite news|last1=Polletta|first1=Maria|date=November 13, 2020|title=Trump attorney tells Maricopa County judge that vote challenge is not about fraud or election theft|work=[[Arizona Republic]]|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/11/12/maricopa-county-judge-hear-trump-team-case-maricopa-county-votes/6260414002/|url-status=live|accessdate=November 14, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116052324/https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/11/12/maricopa-county-judge-hear-trump-team-case-maricopa-county-votes/6260414002/|archive-date=November 16, 2020}}</ref> Additionally, during questioning, none of the witnesses indicated that they had a basis to believe that their vote was improperly discarded; with the only impropriety raised being election workers pressing buttons for them.<ref name="Polletta2" />
 
 During the hearing, the lawyer for the Trump campaign, Kory Langhofer, stated that the plaintiffs were "not alleging fraud" or "that anyone is stealing the election", but were disputing "good faith errors".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blake|first1=Aaron|date=November 13, 2020|title=It goes from bad to worse for the Trump legal team|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/11/13/it-goes-bad-worse-trump-legal-team/|url-status=live|accessdate=November 14, 2020|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20201114033510/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/11/13/it-goes-bad-worse-trump-legal-team/|archivedate=November 14, 2020}}</ref>
 
 On November 13, the lawsuit regarding presidential ballots was dropped, after it became evident that the number of votes potentially to be contested (191) would not overcome Biden's margin of victory in the state (11,414 at the time, with 10,315 uncounted).<ref name=":1">{{cite web|last1=Scannell|first1=Kara|date=November 13, 2020|title=Trump campaign drops Arizona lawsuit requesting review of ballots|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/13/politics/arizona-trump-lawsuit/index.html|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201116052306/https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/13/politics/arizona-trump-lawsuit/index.html|archive-date=November 16, 2020|access-date=November 13, 2020|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
 
 == ''Stevenson v. Ducey'' ==
 On December 4, 2020, members of Arizona Election Integrity Association (AEIA) filed an election contest lawsuit (CV2020-096490) in the Superior Court of Arizona in Maricopa County. The lawsuit challenged a total of 371,498 votes, alleging that the votes were illegally counted. The plaintiffs asked the Court to vacate the certification of Arizona's election results and issue an injunction to stop state election officials from certifying the election, so that the Arizona General Assembly can appoint electors.<ref name=":99">{{cite web|last=Spilsbury|first=David|date=December 3, 2020|title=Case No. CV2020-096490: Petition for Election Contest|url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/12/PetitionforElectionContest.pdf|via=democracydocket.com|access-date=December 21, 2020|archive-date=December 30, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230073758/https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/12/PetitionforElectionContest.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> On December 7, the plaintiffs filed a notice of voluntary dismissal.<ref name=":100">{{Cite web|title=Case No. CV2020-096490: Petitioners' Notice of Voluntary Dismissal Under Rule 41 (a)(1)(A)(i) of the Arizona Rules of Civil Procedure|url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/12/PetitionersNoticeofVolunta.pdf|access-date=2020-12-21|archive-date=2020-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230073758/https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/12/PetitionersNoticeofVolunta.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 == ''Ward v. Jackson'' ==
 On November 30, 2020, an Arizona voter and state Republican Party Chair, Kelli Ward, filed a lawsuit<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Verified Amended Complaint|url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/11/11-30-20-Amend-Verified-Complaint.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201201013551/https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/11/11-30-20-Amend-Verified-Complaint.pdf|archive-date=December 1, 2020|access-date=December 6, 2020|website=Democracy Docket}}</ref> in the Superior Court of Arizona, Maricopa County. Ward challenged the signature verification process, claiming election workers were unfit to verify signatures. Ward also challenged the ballot duplication process, whereby bipartisan county workers transferred votes to new ballots when ballot tabulators could not read them, claiming that observers were not allowed to view the entire process.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Ward v. Jackson|url=https://healthyelections-case-tracker.stanford.edu/detail?id=408|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201206154340/https://healthyelections-case-tracker.stanford.edu/detail?id=408|archive-date=December 6, 2020|access-date=December 6, 2020|website=Stanford-MIT Healthy Elections Project}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Polletta|first=Maria|last2=Randazzo|first2=Ryan|date=December 3, 2020|title=GOP poll watchers testify about problems with duplicate ballots; fewer than 200 votes may be at stake|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/12/03/arizona-republican-party-lawsuit-overturn-election-results-goes-trial/3794819001/|access-date=December 6, 2020|website=The Arizona Republic|language=en-US|archive-date=December 30, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230073841/https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/12/03/arizona-republican-party-lawsuit-overturn-election-results-goes-trial/3794819001/|url-status=live}}</ref> As a remedy, Ward asked the court to decertify the election results, where Biden won by 10,457 votes,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Ortega|first=Bob|date=December 1, 2020|title=Arizona certifies Biden's victory|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/30/politics/joe-biden-arizona-certification/index.html|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201201161518/https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/30/politics/joe-biden-arizona-certification/index.html|archive-date=December 2, 2020|access-date=December 6, 2020|website=CNN}}</ref> and instead award the elector votes to Trump.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Duda|first=Jeremy|date=December 3, 2020|title=Examination finds Maricopa ballot errors didn't affect presidential outcome|url=https://www.azmirror.com/2020/12/03/examination-finds-maricopa-ballot-errors-didnt-affect-presidential-outcome/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201206153046/https://www.azmirror.com/2020/12/03/examination-finds-maricopa-ballot-errors-didnt-affect-presidential-outcome/|archive-date=December 6, 2020|access-date=December 6, 2020|website=Arizona Mirror|language=en-US}}</ref> Attorney Marc Elias represented the defendants, 11 Biden electors, and argued that the issues raised by Ward are "garden-variety errors." Judge Randall Warner dismissed the lawsuit on December 4.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Grayer|first=Annie|last2=Becker|first2=Stephanie|last3=Ortega|first3=Bob|last4=Jimenez|first4=Oscar|date=December 4, 2020|title=Courts hand Trump more losses as attempts to upend election results collapse|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/04/politics/trump-election-defeats-courts/index.html|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201206153613/https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/04/politics/trump-election-defeats-courts/index.html|archive-date=December 6, 2020|access-date=December 6, 2020|website=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Order, Ward v. Jackson|url=https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/11/Order-2.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230073802/https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/45/2020/11/Order-2.pdf|archive-date=December 30, 2020|access-date=December 6, 2020|website=Democracy Docket}}</ref>
 
 After the [[Arizona Supreme Court]] rejected her appeal, concluding that Ward presented no evidence of misconduct, Ward appealed to the Supreme Court.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-12-11|title=Ward takes bid to undo Biden win in Arizona to Supreme Court|url=https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-arizona-phoenix-lawsuits-elections-5e7cc3436ade78e7b60d0bf3aa61ee83|access-date=2020-12-15|website=AP NEWS|archive-date=2020-12-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201230073900/https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-arizona-phoenix-lawsuits-elections-5e7cc3436ade78e7b60d0bf3aa61ee83|url-status=live}}</ref>

 '''David "Dave" Min''' (born March 5, 1976) is an American attorney, professor, and politician. He is the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] senator for [[California's 37th State Senate district|California's 37th Senate district]], which includes portions of [[Orange County, California|Orange County]].<ref>{{cite tweet |user=DLCC |number=1326200219256623110 |date=November 10, 2020 |title=BREAKING: @DaveMinCA just FLIPPED California’s SD-37! }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=BREAKING: Dave Min Elected to California State Senate |url=https://davemin.com/news/victory-announcement/ |work=Dave Min for State Senate |date=8 November 2020}}</ref>  He is an attorney and formerly was an assistant law professor at the [[University of California, Irvine School of Law]] before he became a senator.<ref>{{cite web |title=David Min |url=https://www.law.uci.edu/faculty/full-time/min/ |website=www.law.uci.edu |accessdate=11 November 2020}}</ref> He previously ran in the [[2018 United States House of Representatives elections in California|2018 election]] to represent [[California's 45th congressional district]], but was defeated in the [[nonpartisan blanket primary]] by incumbent Congresswoman [[Mimi Walters]] and fellow UC Irvine professor [[Katie Porter]], who went on to defeat Walters in the general election.<ref>{{cite news |title=2018 California general election results |url=https://elections.cdn.sos.ca.gov/sov/2018-primary/sov/2018-complete-sov.pdf |accessdate=11 November 2020 |work=California Secretary of State}}</ref>  He was elected in the [[2020 California elections|2020 elections]] after defeating [[Costa Mesa]] mayor Katrina Foley in the primary and then by narrowly defeating incumbent senator [[John Moorlach]] in the November election.<ref>{{cite news |title=Democrat Dave Min declares victory over GOP incumbent John Moorlach in 37th Senate District |url=https://www.ocregister.com/2020/11/03/dave-min-takes-lead-over-john-moorlach-in-early-election-results-for-37th-senate-district/ |work=Orange County Register |date=4 November 2020}}</ref>
 
 ==Biography==
 Born in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] to Korean parents who first immigrated to the United States in 1972 to pursue doctoral degrees at [[Brown University]], Min grew up in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].<ref name=nbc>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/policy-nerd-dave-min-wants-give-academia-seat-congress-n760156 |title=‘Policy Nerd’ Dave Min Wants to Give Up Academia for a Seat in Congress |last=Namkung |first=Victoria |date=May 23, 2017 |website=NBC News |access-date=June 6, 2017}}</ref> He went to the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business]] and [[University of Pennsylvania School of Arts and Sciences|School of Art and Sciences]], where he received his undergraduate degrees and graduated [[magna cum laude]]. Min then attended [[Harvard Law School]], where he got his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]<ref name=ucidave />
 
 Prior to his election to the Senate, Min was an assistant law professor at the [[University of California, Irvine]] (UCI). He focused on the [[Bank regulation|law and policy of banking]], [[capital markets]], and [[real estate finance]].<ref name=weekly>{{cite web |url=http://www.ocweekly.com/news/here-comes-min-8016480
  |title=David Min is Second Democrat UCI Law Professor to Challenge Rep. Mimi Walters |last=Coker |first=Matt |date=April 6, 2017 |website=OC Weekly |access-date=June 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/04/06/2-uc-irvine-law-profs-compete-for-congressional-seat/ |title=2 UC Irvine Law Profs Compete for Congressional Seat |last=Sloan |first=Karen |date=April 6, 2017 |website=Law.com |access-date=June 6, 2017}}</ref> He was quoted in the media for his expertise in housing finance and financial market issues.<ref name =ucidave>{{cite web |url=http://www.law.uci.edu/faculty/full-time/min/ |title=David Min |website=[[University of California, Irvine School of Law]] |access-date=June 7, 2017}}</ref> He testified about the impact of [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act|Dodd-Frank Financial Regulations]] to the [[United States House Financial Services Subcommittee on Financial Institutions and Consumer Credit|House Financial Services Subcommittee]] in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?307142-1/impact-dodd-frank-financial-regulation-law|title=Impact of Dodd-Frank Financial Regulation Law|website=C-SPAN.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-25}}</ref>
 
 ==Politics==
 After graduating from [[Harvard Law School]], Min worked in financial regulation. Min was a staff attorney at the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]], [[United States Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs|Banking Committee]] counsel for [[Sen. Chuck Schumer]],<ref name="hill">{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/330564-dems-crowd-primaries-to-challenge-gop-reps |title=Dems crowd primaries to challenge GOP reps |last=Hagen |first=Lisa |date=April 26, 2017 |website=The Hill |access-date=June 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2018/02/27/contested-endorsement-california-democratic-party-convention/|title=The Story Behind the California Democratic Party Convention’s Floor Fracas|last=Dayen|first=David|date=2018-02-27|website=The Intercept|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-25}}</ref> and counsel and senior policy advisor for the [[United States Congress Joint Economic Committee]]<ref name="weekly" /> until becoming the Associate Director for Financial Markets Policy at the [[think tank]] [[Center for American Progress]].<ref name="ocreg">{{cite web |url=http://www.ocregister.com/2017/04/05/dave-min-a-uc-irvine-law-professor-will-challenge-rep-mimi-walters/ |title=Dave Min, a UC Irvine law professor, will challenge Rep. Mimi Walters |last=Wisckol |first=Martin |date=April 5, 2017 |website=Orange County Register |access-date=June 6, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/world/2017/04/684_227539.html |title=Korean-American law professor runs for US Congress |last=Dong-chan |first=Jhoo |date=April 13, 2017 |website=The Korea Times |access-date=June 6, 2017}}</ref> There, he supervised the efforts of a team of specialists on housing finance reform, called the Mortgage Finance Working Group.<ref name="Intercept" />
 
 ===2018 Congressional campaign===
-Min announced his House candidacy on April 5, 2017, challenging incumbent Rep. [[Mimi Walters]] in [[California's 45th congressional district]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newuniversity.org/2018/04/03/where-congressional-candidates-from-uci-stand-on-local-and-national-issues/|title=Where Congressional Candidates from UCI Stand on Local and National Issues – New University|website=www.newuniversity.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-25}}</ref> Min has stated he was inspired to run for Congress after President [[Donald Trump]] [[Immigration policy of Donald Trump#Proposed Muslim immigration ban|temporarily suspended immigration]] from certain predominantly Muslim countries, which he said was a "slap in the face" to the son of two immigrants, especially after Walters refused to directly condemn those actions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/27/politics/candidates-of-color-age-of-trump/index.html|title=Outraged by Trump, these candidates of color are now running for office|last=Summers|first=Juana|work=CNN|access-date=2018-05-25}}</ref>
+Min announced his House candidacy on April 5, 2017, challenging incumbent Rep. [[Mimi Walters]] in [[California's 45th congressional district]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newuniversity.org/2018/04/03/where-congressional-candidates-from-uci-stand-on-local-and-national-issues/|title=Where Congressional Candidates from UCI Stand on Local and National Issues – New University|website=www.newuniversity.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-25}}</ref> Min stated he was inspired to run for Congress after President [[Donald Trump]] [[Immigration policy of Donald Trump#Proposed Muslim immigration ban|temporarily suspended immigration]] from certain predominantly Muslim countries, which he said was a "slap in the face" to the son of two immigrants, especially after Walters refused to directly condemn those actions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/27/politics/candidates-of-color-age-of-trump/index.html|title=Outraged by Trump, these candidates of color are now running for office|last=Summers|first=Juana|work=CNN|access-date=2018-05-25}}</ref>
 
 Min received the endorsement of the [[California Democratic Party]] at its State Convention in February 2018 after a contentious floor fight where he barely received the necessary 60% of the vote.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/essential/la-pol-ca-essential-politics-updates-dave-min-gets-democratic-endorsement-for-1519593051-htmlstory.html |title=Dave Min gets Democratic endorsement for Congress after intense fight on the convention floor |last=Mai-Duc |first=Christine |date=February 25, 2018 |website=Los Angeles Times |access-date=February 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/03/california-is-not-as-liberal-as-you-think.html|title=California Is Not As Liberal As You Think|last=Nwanevu|first=Osita|work=Slate Magazine|access-date=2018-05-25|language=en}}</ref>
 
-Min aired [[attack ad]]s against two Democratic opponents, in one criticizing Katie Porter's ties to pro-women's group [[EMILY's List]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/first-read-s-morning-clips-senate-absolutely-play-mcconnell-says-n875311 |title=First Read's Morning Clips: Midterm Madness |date=May 18, 2018 |website=NBC News |access-date=May 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.davemin.com/mintvad/ |title=New TV ads in CA-45 Exposes False Claims from Katie Porter and Brian Forde |date=May 22, 2018 |website=Dave Min for Congress |access-date=May 22, 2018}}</ref> [[Axios (website)|AXIOS]] analyzed the first attack ad and concluded "Bottom line: Min's attack line doesn't hold water."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.axios.com/bitcoin-battle-california-election-dave-mim-brian-forde-525322bf-3198-40b5-8fb5-5fb9d8d2b4f7.html |title=New attack in politics: exploiting Bitcoin fears |last=Primack  |first=Dan |date=May 21, 2018 |website=Axios |access-date=May 21, 2018 }}</ref> An analysis of the ads by ''[[The Intercept]]'' described the validity of their claims as "strange" and "between being somewhat legitimate and really shaky".<ref name="Intercept">{{cite web |url=https://theintercept.com/2018/05/25/in-a-california-house-race-the-democratic-partys-candidate-is-going-to-war-against-elizabeth-warrens/ |title=In a California House Race, THe Democratic Party's Candidate is Going to War Against Elixabeth Warren's |last=Dayen  |first=David |date=May 25, 2018 |website=The Intercept |access-date=May 25, 2018}}</ref>
+Min aired [[attack ad]]s against two Democratic opponents, in one criticizing [[Katie Porter]]'s ties to pro-women's group [[EMILY's List]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/first-read/first-read-s-morning-clips-senate-absolutely-play-mcconnell-says-n875311 |title=First Read's Morning Clips: Midterm Madness |date=May 18, 2018 |website=NBC News |access-date=May 19, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.davemin.com/mintvad/ |title=New TV ads in CA-45 Exposes False Claims from Katie Porter and Brian Forde |date=May 22, 2018 |website=Dave Min for Congress |access-date=May 22, 2018}}</ref> [[Axios (website)|Axios]] analyzed the first attack ad and concluded "Bottom line: Min's attack line doesn't hold water."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.axios.com/bitcoin-battle-california-election-dave-mim-brian-forde-525322bf-3198-40b5-8fb5-5fb9d8d2b4f7.html |title=New attack in politics: exploiting Bitcoin fears |last=Primack  |first=Dan |date=May 21, 2018 |website=Axios |access-date=May 21, 2018 }}</ref> An analysis of the ads by ''[[The Intercept]]'' described the validity of their claims as "strange" and "between being somewhat legitimate and really shaky".<ref name="Intercept">{{cite web |url=https://theintercept.com/2018/05/25/in-a-california-house-race-the-democratic-partys-candidate-is-going-to-war-against-elizabeth-warrens/ |title=In a California House Race, THe Democratic Party's Candidate is Going to War Against Elixabeth Warren's |last=Dayen  |first=David |date=May 25, 2018 |website=The Intercept |access-date=May 25, 2018}}</ref>
