 {{Dead link |date=May 2018}}
 </ref>
 
-Min has criticised Walters for living outside of the district and for refusing to hold public or in-person town halls.<ref name=nbc />
+Min criticized Walters for living outside of the district and for refusing to hold public or in-person town halls.<ref name=nbc />
+
+Min ultimately came in third place in the primary election behind Walters and Porter.
 
 ===2020 State Senate Campaign===
 In the fall of 2020, Min defeated incumbent State Senator [[John Moorlach]] to represent the [[California's 37th State Senate district]] with 51.2% of the vote.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-11-04|title=Democrat Dave Min declares victory over GOP incumbent John Moorlach in 37th Senate District|url=https://www.ocregister.com/2020/11/03/dave-min-takes-lead-over-john-moorlach-in-early-election-results-for-37th-senate-district|access-date=2020-11-29|website=Orange County Register|language=en-US}}</ref> He assumed office on December 7, 2020.
 
 ==Personal life==
 Min is married to Jane Stoever, a Clinical Professor of Law at [[UC Irvine]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.law.uci.edu/faculty/full-time/stoever/
  |title=Jane K. Stoever
  |website=[[University of California, Irvine School of Law]]
  |access-date=June 8, 2017
  }}</ref>
 His wife works on domestic violence issues.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/california-primaries-negative-campaigning|title=Could Negative Campaigning in California Primaries Dampen Democratic Energy?|last=Bowman|first=Bridget|date=2018-05-24|work=Roll Call|access-date=2018-05-25|language=en}}</ref>
 
 They have three children.<ref name=nbc />

 ==Mississippi House of Representatives==
 
 ===Elections===
 In April 2006, incumbent Republican State Representative Leonard Bentz of Mississippi's 116th House District resigned because he was appointed to the [[Mississippi Public Service Commission]]. Palazzo sought election to the vacated seat, defeating Democratic candidate Maryann Graczyk, an education lobbyist, and Republican George Emile, a funeral home director, 51%–26%–24%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=396624 |title=MS State House 116 – Special Election Race – Nov 07, 2006 |publisher=Ourcampaigns.com |access-date=2015-03-14}}</ref> In 2007, running unopposed, he was elected to a full term.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=396601 |title=MS State House 116 Race |date= November 6, 2007 |publisher= Ourcampaigns.com |access-date= 2015-03-14}}</ref>
 
 ===Committee assignments===
 Palazzo served on the Banking and Financial Services, Juvenile Justice, Labor, Select Committee on the Gulf Coast Disaster, and the Wildlife, Fisheries and Parks Committees.<ref name="state1"/>
 
 ==U.S. House of Representatives==
 
 ===Elections===
 
 ====2010====
 {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Mississippi, 2010#District 4}}
 Palazzo entered the Republican primary for [[Mississippi's 4th congressional district]] and won the nomination with 57% of the vote. He faced 10-term Democratic incumbent [[Gene Taylor (Mississippi)|Gene Taylor]] in the general election. Although the 4th district had turned almost solidly Republican at the federal level, Taylor held the seat without serious difficulty from 1996 onward. His voting record had been very conservative even by [[Mississippi Democratic Party|Mississippi Democratic]] standards, and he'd often broken with his party. Palazzo established himself as Taylor's strongest opponent since 1996. In particular, he attacked Taylor for supporting [[Nancy Pelosi]] for House Speaker in 2006 and 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1010/44119.html|title=Taylor: I voted for McCain – Jessica Taylor|publisher=Politico.Com|access-date=2010-11-03}}</ref> He was endorsed by [[Sarah Palin]] and in the November 2010 general election, Palazzo defeated Taylor 52%–47%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=496790 |title=MS – District 04 Race – Nov 02, 2010 |publisher=Ourcampaigns.com |access-date=2015-03-14}}</ref>

 ====2012====
 {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Mississippi, 2012#District 4}}
 In the Republican primary, Palazzo defeated two challengers with 74% of the vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=751580 |title=MS District 04 – R Primary Race – Mar 13, 2012 |publisher=Ourcampaigns.com |access-date=2015-03-14}}</ref> In the November election, he defeated Democratic candidate Matthew Moore 64%–29%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=724373 |title=MS – District 04 Race – Nov 06, 2012 |publisher=Ourcampaigns.com |access-date=2015-03-14}}</ref>
 
 ====2014====
 {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Mississippi, 2014#District 4}}
 In the 2014 Republican primary, Palazzo faced his predecessor, Gene Taylor, and three other challengers.<ref name = "Msbusiness">{{cite web|url=http://msbusiness.com/blog/2014/06/05/palazzo-defeats-taylor-4th-congressional-district-primary/ |title=Palazzo defeats Taylor in 4th Congressional District primary|publisher=Msbusiness.com |date=2014-06-05 |access-date=2015-03-14}}</ref> Taylor switched parties in a bid to return to his former House seat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/senate-races/199634-ex-rep-gene-taylor-becomes-republican-to-run-again|title=Ex-Rep. switches parties to run again|publisher=Thehill.com|last=Joseph|first=Cameron|access-date=March 1, 2014}}</ref> Taylor actively campaigned and drew large numbers of Democrats into the Republican primary.<ref name = "Msbusiness" /> Palazzo was targeted by the [[Club for Growth]] in the primary.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jaffe |first=Alexandra |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/house-races/285193-club-for-growth-targeting-rino-republicans |title=Club for Growth targeting 9 'RINO' Republicans for primary challenges – The Hill's Ballot Box |publisher=Thehill.com |date=February 27, 2013 |access-date=February 19, 2015}}</ref> Palazzo won 50.5% of the vote while Taylor received 43%.<ref name = "Msbusiness" />
 
 On November 4, 2014, Palazzo easily defeated his 2012 general election opponent, Matt Moore, 69.9% to 24.3%; four minor party or independent candidates accounted for 3.8% of the vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sos.ms.gov/Elections-Voting/Pages/2014-General-Elections.aspx |title=2014 General Elections |publisher=Sos.ms.gov |access-date=2015-03-14}}</ref>
 
 ====2016====
 In the Republican primary, Palazzo ran unopposed for the first time in his political career.  On November 8, Palazzo garnered 65.2% of the vote defeating Democrat Mark Gladney and two minor candidates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/2016-election/results/map/house/mississippi/ |title=2016 Mississippi House Election Results|date=2016-11-11 |access-date=2016-11-12}}</ref>
